subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Theravada vs. Mahayana: Two Paths, One Buddha
description: A 60-second lesson on Theravada vs. Mahayana: Two Paths, One Buddha.

hook.text: One branch says enlightenment is for monks. The other says it's for everyone. Buddhism split, and both sides are right.

buildup.text: Theravada ('Teaching of the Elders') is the older, stricter form. It dominates Southeast Asia. Monks are central.

discovery.text: Mahayana ('Great Vehicle') opened enlightenment to laypeople. Bodhisattvas delay their own nirvana to help others.

twist.text: Mahayana spawned Zen, Pure Land, and Tibetan Buddhism. The 'simpler' branch produced the most complex traditions.

climax.text: Buddhism's split proves that one teaching can be read in opposite ways. Diversity isn't a bug; it's a feature of faith.

punchline.text: Two branches, one Buddha. Buddhism proves faith thrives through diversity.

quiz.question: What is the main difference between Theravada and Mahayana Buddhism?
options: Theravada focuses on monks; Mahayana opens enlightenment to everyone
